questionAnswers.messageText: Moesman Developed Moesman in Europe in the aftermath of World War I, the surrealist movement is best known for its juxtaposition of uncommon imagery and focus on the unconscious.

questionAsked.messageText: What did people think of De Peer?

questionAnswers.messageText: I saw De Peer at the Stedelijk Museum in 1931. De Peer was completely incomprehensible, I remember being stumped by this strange figure.
Looking back on the exhibition in the Stedelijk Museum, Moesman was far ahead of his time.
Back then, a painting like this was considered completely taboo.
Johannes Moesman was the only Dutch artist to be formally ranked among the surrealists.

Moesman used surrealism as an opportunity to indulge his sexual fantasies on the canvas â€“ with the excuse that the images were produced by the subconscious, for which he could not be held responsible.
